p.seg: As for the Way,
it covers the heavens and supports the earth,
Extends beyond the Four Regions
It cuts beyond the eight points of the compass.
It is high beyond reach;
It is deep beyond fathoming;
It envelops Heaven and Earth,
And it endows what is (still) shapeless.
Flowing from its source it becomes a gushing spring, [Like a source it flows on like a spring it bubbles forth
What was empty slowly becomes full;
First turbid and then surging forward,
What was murky slowly becomes clear.
Hence, stand it up vertically, and it stuffs up the heavens and the earth;
Lay it horizontally on its side, and it fills the four seas.
Dealing it out becomes endless,
yet is without morning or evening. (and it has no ebb and tide)
Unroll it, and it blankets the six directions;
Roll it up, and it is less than a handful.
Compact, it can stretch out; (or: cause things to expand)
Dark, it can be bright; (or: make things bright)
Weak, it can be strong, (or: make things strong)
Pliant, it can be unbending. (or: make things rigid)
It stretches over the four cables holding up the heavens, and harbors within itself the yin and the yang; (含 does not mean "restrain")
It broadens the cosmos and brightens the sun, the moon, and the stars.
†It is the thinnest of gruels,†
The finest and most subtle texture.
By virtue of it, mountains are high;
By virtue of it, abysses are deep;
By virtue of it, animals run; (NOT: can run)
By virtue of it, birds fly; (NOT: can fly)
By virtue of it, the sun and moon are bright;
By virtue of it, the stars and celestial bodies rotate;
By virtue of it, the unicorn rambles about,
By virtue of it, the phoenix soars.
The two kings, the Tai Huang and the Gu Huang, (Fuxi and Nüwa)
Got hold of the handle of dao
And stood at the center.
In spirit they roamed together with the demiurge of transformation (the transformations of things)
To bring peace to the world.
Hence (working the handles of dao), they can: Move like the heavens and stay still like the earth.
Turning like a wheel without flagging,
Flowing like water without cease,
They begin and end at the same time as the myriad things.
Just as when the wind rises, the clouds steam forth,
There was nothing to which they did not respond;
Just as when the thunder crashes, the rain falls,
They are never at a loss in their response.
Ghosts appear, gods disappear, (Like spirits, like the lightning) (LeBlanc comes closer: avec la rapidité des esprits et des manes)
Dragons fly away, phoenixes alight. (Like dragons, Like phoenixes)
Like the potter's wheel spinning, like the hub whirling,
Going full circle they start going round again.
Garved and chiseled,
They return to being an uncarved block.
Doing what they did with no ulterior motive,
they accorded with dao;
saying what they said with no ulterior motive,
they were in communion with de;
happy and easy with no sense of self-importance,
what they gained was in harmony;
though they had a myriad of different manifestations,
they yet accorded with each of these things in their various natures;
their spirits resided in the tiniest tip of an autumn down,
and yet were larger than the sum total of the cosmos.
Their de embraced the heavens and the earth and brought harmony to the yin and the yang,
Ordered the four seasons and regulated the five phases.
Brooding over things and nurturing them,
They produced the myriad things in all their variety.
They provided moistening nourishment to the grasses and trees
And penetrated the minerals and rocks.
The birds and beasts grew large and tall,
With coats glossy and sleek,
Wings sprouting out
and horns growing,
animals did not miscarry
and birds did not lay addled eggs,
fathers were spared the suffering of mourning their sons
and elder brothers were spared the grief of weeping over the younger ones,
Children were not orphaned,
Nor were wives widowed,
Evil confluences of the yin and the yang did not appear
Nor did ominous celestial portents occur.
This all came of the de they harbored within.
The primordial dao:
Engenders the myriad things without appropriating them,
Moulds things into various shapes by the process of transformation without claiming stewardship over them.
Creatures moving about on legs and breathing through their mouths,
insects wriggling and flying about
they owe their life to it,
yet realize not they ought to be grateful;
they owe their death to it,
yet are incapable of harboring a grudge.
Those who benefit from it cannot sing its praise,
while those who fail through it cannot condemn it.
Regardless of how much is gathered and stored it is none the richer;
Regardless of how much is doled out and bestowed it is none the poorer.
So minute and tenuous = yet there is no getting to the bottom of it;
So fine and subtle - yet there is no using it up.
Piling it up does not make it taller,
Collapsing it does not make it shorter;
Adding to it does not make it more numerous,
Taking away from it does not make it less numerous;
Whittling it away does not meke it thinner,
Slaughtering does not leave it devastated;
Boring into it does not make it deeper,
Filling it in does not make it shallower.
Hazy and nebulouos,
It cannot be taken as an image;
Nebulous and hazy,
It is not spent through use;
Obscure and dark,
It responds to what is without form;
Deep and dark,
It makes no move in vain.
It is rolled up and unrolled along with the pliant and the unbending;
It turns upwards and downwards with the yin and the yang.
In their charioting, Ping Yi and Da Bing of antiquity:
Mounted the thunder chariot
And used the cloud dragons as their six horses.
They rambled about in the fine mists,
Galloped around in the hazy and nebulous,
And, ever more distant and ever higher, they made the trip of all trips.
They would pass over frost and snow without leaving tracks,
And with the sun shining on them they would cast no shadow.
Swirling on a typhoon they spiraled upward,
Negotiating mountains and rivers
And leaping over the peaks of Kunlun,
They pushed open the Changhe gates
And entered through the Gateway of Heaven.
A charioteer in an age in decline:
Even with a light vehicle, fine horses,
A strong whip and sharp goads,
Cannot hope to overtake them.
Hence, the person of great stature:
Being placidly free of all worries
And serenly without thoughts for the morrow,
Has the heavens as his canopy,
The earth as his boxframe,
The four seasons as his horses,
And the yin and the yang as his charioteer.
He mounts the clouds and climbs beyond the skies,
To be with the demiurge of change.
Doing as he pleases and following a freer rhythm
He gallops the great abode.
He walks hsi horses when he should walk them,
He runs them hard when he should run them.
He gets the god of rain to sprinkle his path
And the god of wind to sweep away the dust.
With lighting as his whip
And thunder as his wheels,
Above he rambles in the free and roaming vastness,
Below he goes out of the gates of boundlessness.
Having scanned all round and left nothing out,
Remaining whole he returns to guard what is within.
He manages the four corners of the earth
Yet always returns to the pivot.
Thus, with the heavens as his canopy,
there is nothing that is unsheltered;
With the earth as his boxframe,
there is nothing that has no conveyance;
With the four seasons as horses,
there is nothing that is unemployed;
With the yin and the yang as charioteers,
there is nothing that is lacking.
Hence, he travels fast without pitching
And travels far without fatigue.
Without taxing his four limbs
And without draining the keenness of his hearing and sight,
He knows the lay and the boundaries of the various divisions and quadrants of the cosmos.
How is this so?
It is because he has his hands on the control handles of dao
and rambles in the land of the inexhaustible.
Hence, there is nothing you can do about the world.
You can only follow what is natural in pushing the myriad things aheard.
There is no getting to the bottom of the changes they undergo.
You can only grasp the essential destination and lead them there.
It is because the mirror and water do not, in anticipation,
equip themselves with cleverness,
that the shapes they come into contact with cannot but show themselves as they are: square, round, bent, and straight.
Hence, an echo does not resound as it like,
and a shadow is not something that is cast once and for all.
The likeness of the sound and shape
is attained without fuss.
A man is quiescent when born.
This is his Heaven-endowed nature.
He moves when aroused.
This is the stirring of that nature.
The human spirit responds when things come on the scene.
This is the movement of the intellect.
When the intellct comes into contact with things,
Feelings of attraction and aversion are produced.
Where these feelings of attraction and aversion have taken shape,
And the intellect has been enticed from the outside,
One is unable to return to himself,
And the Heavenly principles in him are destroyed.
Thus, one who understands dao
Does not barter what belongs to Heaven for what is man's.
While externally he is transformed along with the transformation of things,
Internally be does not become other than what he is really like.
Lacking in everything, he is able to satisfy their needs.
Though constantly on the move, he will always be waiting for them where they put up for the night.
Everything regardless of size or shape
Is equipped with what it properly ought to have.
Though the myriad things come bounding along
In utter disarray,
He does not lose his count on them.
Therefore, he is on top of the people, yet they do not find him heavy;
He is in front of the multitude, yet they do not find he blocks the view.
The empire turns to him
And the evil and depraved fear him.
It is because he does not contend with the myrial things
that one are able to contend with him.
A person can fail to fill his basket after spending an entire day
fishing beside the river.
Though he has all manner of hooks, barbs, and lures,
uses fine line and tempting bait,
and in addition to this, has the technique of a Zhan He or Juan Xuan,
he won't be able to vie with the fishing nets in the size of the catch.
Though an archer in shooting birds in flight draws the Wu Hao Bow,
fits a fine arrow of Qi to the bowstring,
And reinforces this with the expertise of an Yi or Feng Mengzi,
He still won't be able to vie with the nets
in the number of birds he catches.
Why is this so?
It is because what he has in hand is small.
If one streches the world as his bird-basket
and converts the rivers and seas into a fishnet,
how will a fish or a bird ever manage to get away!
Thus, an arrow is not as effective as a corded arrow,
A corded arrow is not as effective as a net, And a net is not as effective as the Formless Image.
To let go of the great dao and rely on small devices
Is no different from trying to use a crab to catch a mouse
Or a toad to catch a flea
Far from these devices being adequate to prohibit wickedness and stem depravity,
disorder will in fact be on the increase.
In ancient times, Gun of Xia constructed city walls eighty feet high,
yet the various nobles turned against him
and in the lands beyond the seas men became crafty.
(His son) Yu, realizing that the world was disaffected,
demolished the walls, filled in the moats,
gave away the accumulated wealth,
burned the armor and weapons,
And treated all with beneficence.
The lands beyond the seas acknowledged his suzerainty
And the barbarian tribes came to offer their tributes.
And when he assembled the various nobles at Tushan,
There were ten thousand states bringing gifts of ceremonial jade and cloth.
Thus, when a man harbors a calculating heart In his breast,
The quality of his person is contaminated
and his spirituality is not kept whole.
If a man lacks knowledge of what is harbored in his owe person,
how is he going to be able to win over those at a distance?
Hence, stronger armor calls forth sharper weapons;
the erection of city walls calls forth the battering ram for breaching them.
It is like using boiling water to calm water on the boil, the agitation will grow even worse.
Hence, this can be likened to whipping a mad dog
Or taking a crop to a kicking horse,
With the intention of training them.
Even a Yi Yin or a Zao Fu would be unable to transform them.
But where one does not harbor A heart that covets its meat,
He can pull the tail of even a hungry tiger.
How much more the tails of animals such as horses and dogs!
Thus, those who embody dao do not exert themselves yet are never at wits' end
While those who rely on devices are worn out with nothing to show for it in the end.
Harsh laws and severe punishments
are not practices that will perpetuate hegemony or kingship,
and the repeated use of a horse-whip
is not the way to get to a distant destination.
With eyesight that enables him
to make out the point of a needle beyond a hundred paces,
Li Zhu was not able to spot fishes in the deep.
With hearing that enables him
to bring the sound of the eight winds into a harmony,
Music Master Kuang was not able to hear beyond ten li.
Thus, if we rely on the ability of one man:
The management of even a half-acre tract of land will be too much for us,
But is we leave dao to its own devices
And base ourselves on the natural course of the cosmos,
Then the regulation of all of the universe up, down, and in all directions is not worth bothering about.
Hence, Yu in draining the accumulated waters
Took the water as his mentor,
And Shen Nong in sowing grain
Took seedlings as model for his instruction.
Floating plants take root in water,
Land plants take root in the soil,
Birds fly by stroking emptiness,
Animals run by treading solidity.
Alligators and dragons make their home in water,
Tigers and leopards dwell in the mountains.
This is the nature of the world.
Two pieces of wood when rubbed together ignite;
When kept close to fire, metal becomes molten;
Round things normally spin,
Hollow things chiefly float.
It is their natural inclination to do so.
Hence, when the spring winds come they bring the timely rains,
and the myriad things are produced and nourished.
Feathered creatures incubate and hatch their eggs,
Furred creatures conceive and give birth to their young,
Plants and trees bloom
And birds and animals are oviparous and viviparous.
Without anyone ever seeing the actual doing,
The deed is accomplished.
When the autumn winds bring the frost,
Vegetation is injured ang snaps,
Eagles adn falcons sweep down on their prey,
Swarming insects hibernate,
Plants and trees put down their roots,
And fishes and turtles make for the deep.
Without anyone ever seeing the actual doing,
Things disappear without a trace.
Trees dwellers nest in the foliage,
Water dwellers live in underwater caves.
Birds and beasts have beds of straw,
Human beings have houses.
For dwelling on land the rearing of cattle and horses is suitable,
And for travel by boat abundance in waterway is suitable.
The Xiongnu territory produces animal hides for clothing,
While the Wu and Yue territories produce hemp for garments.
Each produces what is badly needed
In defense against the dry and wet;
Each takes advantage of the places in which they are situated
To ward off the cold and heat.
They all get what is suitable,
And what is produced meets a local need.
Viewing it from this perspective,
The myriad things have been so-of-themselves from the beginning.
What room is there for interference by the sage?
To the south of the Jiuyi mountain region,
There is little to be done on land whereas there is much to be done in the water.
For this reason, the people Cut their hair and tattoo their bodies
To look like scaly reptiles.
They wear briefs in place of trousers
For wading and swimming;
They have their short sleeves rolled up
For poling their boats.
This is to avail themselves of what is convenient for the environment.
To the north of the Yan men Pass,
The Di barbarians do not eat grain.
They set great store by men in their prime and look down on the aged,
And it is custom to value virility.
Men never slacken their bowstrings
Nor do they unbridle their horses,
In order to be ever on the ready.
Thus, when Yu went to the Country of the Naked,
He took off his clothing before entering
And put it on again before departing.
This was basing his actions on local custom.
If in transplanting trees a person
neglects the natural balance of their yin and yang,
they will all wither up and die.
Thus: when the tangerine tree is carried north across the Yangtze River,
it is transformed into the bitter-orange tree.
The gray thrush does not cross the Ji River,
And the badger dies when it crosses the Wen River.
Their form and basic nature should not be changed,
and neither should the circumstances under which they live be altered.
Hence, one who understands dao
Returns to his limpidity and stillness,
And one who knows all there is to know about things
Always ends up with nonactivity.
If one nourishes his nature with tranquillity
And lodges his spirit in emptiness,
Then he has entered the Gateway of Heaven.
By "Heaven" is meant
Pure and unadulterated like uncarved wood and undyed silk,
Original simplicity and sheer whiteness,
Which has never been admixed with anythings else.
By "man" is meant
Studying each other and exercising one's knowledge and presuppositions,
Being crafty and deceptive to others,
In order to get on in the world
And to be able to deal with the vulgar.
Thus, an ox's having cloven hoofs and horns,
And a horse's having a mane and uncloven hoofs
Is what is "Heaven";
Bridling a horse's mouth
And boring an ox's nose
is "man."
Those who follow Heaven
ramble about with dao,
Where those who accede to man
have dealings with the vulgar.
Now, the reason that one cannot discuss the "big" with fish in a well
is because they are cooped up in a narrow space.
The reason that one cannot discuss "winter" with the summer insects
is because their life is restricted to one season.
The reason that we cannot discuss "the ultimate dao" with someone whose knowledge is partial
Is because he is bound by vulgar customs
and fettered by what he has been taught.
Thus, the sage does not adulterate Heaven with man,
And does not allow desire to disturb his actual nature.
He hits the mark without planning,
His word is trusted without his having to speak,
He succeeds without deliberating,
He accomplishes without doing.
His purity reaches up to the mansion of the spirits
And he is a comrade of the demiurge of change.
A good swimmer is sure to drown,
And a good rider is sure to fall from his mount.
Each through what he is fond of doing
Ironically brings calamity on himself.
Hence, one who is fond of meddling is never known to escape injury,
And one who contends over profit always ends up in desperate straits.
In ancient times, Gong Gong butted the Buzhou mountain so violently
That it caused the earth to slope to the southeast,
But in contending with Gao Xin for the throne,
He ended up in a watery grave,
With his clan exterminated,
And his ancestral sacrifices coming to an end.
King Yi of Yue, on the other hand, fled to the mountain caves,
But the people of Yue smoked him out
And ultimately he had no choice but to become their king.
Viewing it from this perspective:
Success lies in the opportune moment
and not in contention;
Orderly government lies in dao
and not in the sagacious leader.
Because earth dwells below
and does not contend for a higher station,
It is safe and secure;
Because water flows downward
and does not contend for the lead,
It flows rapidly instead of slowly.
In antiquity, Shun tilled land in the Li mountain area,
and in a year, the farmers were vying to occupy the stony and barren land,
yielding the rich and fertile plots to others.;
when he fished on the banks of the river,
in a year, the fishermen were contending to occupy the stretches of shallow, rushing water,
yielding the nooks and deep pools to others.
At that time,
he spoke no words of instruction
nor gestured any commands,
And yet, because he harbored dark de in his heart,
His transforming influence galloped everywhere with spirited efficacy.
Had Shun not been genuine in his purpose,
Even if he were to try to win them over by persuasion from door to door,
He would still be unable to transform even a single person.
Hence, great indeed
is the unspoken dao!
To be able to govern the San Miao,
Bring the Yu people to court,
Draw the Country of the Naked
And the Su Shen into the Chinese orbit,
And to be able to transform customs and conventions
without issuing orders or commands,
is to act secretly within one's heart.
How could legal restrictions and punishments in themselves ever
be enough to bring this about!
Hence, the sage inwardly cultivates that which is the root
insteat of outwardly putting ornament on that which is the tip.
He preserves his spirit
and puts aside his cleverness.
Quiescently he does nothing, yet leaves nothing undone;
serenely he does not impose order on anything, yet there is nothing that is not ord
By "doing nothing"
is meant not being ahead of things in taking action;
by "leaving nothing undone"
is meant making use of what is done by other things;
by "not imposing order"
is meant not putting in a substitute for what is so-of-itself;
by "nothing not being properly ordered"
is meant making use of the mutual recognitioin that obtains among things.
The myriad things have their progenitor,
Yet he alone knows to abide by the root;
The events of the world have a source out of which they come,
Yet he alone knows to abide by the gateway.
Thus, to get to the end of that which has no end
and to get to the bounds of that which has no bounds,
to go on throwing back the image of things without getting dizzy
and to go on reponding to sounds without running out of echoes:
this is what is called "Heaven's release."
Thus, the person who has attained dao
is weak of purpose yet forceful in action;
His heart is empty yet his response to things is always as it should be.
What is meant by being "weak of purpose" is:
Being pliant and placid,
He takes his refuge in the timorous
And pursues his actions in what cannot be done;
Serenely without thoughts for the morrow
He never anticipates the opportune moment,
And freewheeling, he never goes against the myriad things;
Never taking the lead
He responds only when stimulated.
Hence, the exalted necessarily takes the lowly as title,
And the lofty necessarily takes the base as foundation.
It means lodging in the small to encompass the large,
Dwelling in the central to regulate the peripheral,
Practicing the pliant yet achieving the unbending,
Exercising the weak yet attaining the strong.
Transforming and setting in motion,
And attaining dao of the One,
He is able to rectify the many by using the few.
What is meant by "forceful in action" is:
In responding to the unforeseen in an emergency
And warding off adversities,
There is nothing his strength cannot overcome,
And there is no enemy that he cannot get on top of.
In responding to the workings of transformation he gauges the most opportune moment
And nothing is able to obstruct him.
Hence, those who want to be unbending
necessarily watch over it by pliancy,
And those who want to be strong
necessarily guard it by weakness.
The accumulation of pliancy results in unbendingness
And the accumulation of weakness results in strength;
Observe what is being accumulated,
And you will know which direction it is heading for: fortune or calamity.
Strength overcomes that which is inferior to itself;
When it comes to its equal there will be a draw.
Weakness overcomes that which is superior to itself, (己 still personal)
Its might being immeasurable.
Thus, a weapon that is unyielding will break;
A piece of wood that is stiff will snap;
A piece of leather that is hard will split.
The teeth being harder than the tongue
Are the first to wear out.
Hence, the pliant and the weak
are the trunk of life,
While the hard and strong
are the companions of deaeth.
To sing the lead
is the road to a dead end,
Whereas to follow behind in making a move
is the source of winning through.
How do we know this is the case?
The average lifespan of man is seventy years,
but with all our choices and goals,
we regret every day what we did the day before
and in this way we reach the end of our life.
Thus, Qu Boyu, at fifty years of age,
realized that he was wrong at forty-nine.
Why?
It is difficult for the person taking the lead to be wise,
While it is easy for the one coming behind to achieve results.
When a person who leads the way climbs to a high place,
The one coming behind hoists himself up by grabbing onto him;
When the person who leads the way steps over gaps on the way down,
The one coming behind treads on him as a stepping-stone;
When the person who leads the way stumbles and falls into a hole,
The one coming behind takes counsel;
When the person who leads the way is routed,
The one coming behind turns his back on him.
Viewing it from this perspective,
the person who leads the way is the target which attracts the arrows, taking them away from those coming behind.
It is like the difference between the butt end of a weapon shaft and the blade.
The blade braves danger While the butt end of the shaft is at no risk.
Why?
It is thanks to the rear position the butt end occupies, Which is screened and covered.
This is a truth open to the view of even the most ordinary man
Yet the superior and wise are never able to act on it.
By "coming behind"
is not meant being stagnant, numb,
and inert, Rather,
it means putting store in always being in accord with that which is necessarily so, and being appropriate to the moment.
When a person grasps the principles of dao and uses them to match change,
then he controls others whether he is in the lead
or in the rear.
Why is this?
Because he does not let go of the means to control others,
giving others no chance of controlling him.
The right moment becomes the wrong
Before one can take a breath.
One who acts too soon anticipates the opportunity,
And one who acts too late gets left behind.
The sun revolves, the moon wheels its course,
And the right moment waits for no man.
Thus, the sage values an inch of time
over a foot of precious jade.
It is because the right moment is so hard to catch and so easy to miss.
When Yu was in hot pursuit of the critical moment,
He would not stop to pick up a sandal that had slipped off
Or look back after a snagged cap.
It was not that he was vying to get ahead of others,
but rather that he was vying to catch the right moment.
Hence, the sage abides by the limpid dao and embraces the principle of femininity.
In taking advantage of what is already there and in responding to change,
He always stays in the rear and does not take the lead.
Pliant and weak, he is calm;
Relaxed and peaceful, he is poised.
But in assailing the big or grinding down the hard,
There are none that can vie with him for the lead.
In the world there is nothing
more pliant and weak than water
And yet it is great beyond reckoning
And deep beyond fathoming.
In length it ends only in the interminable
And in distance it merges into the boundless;
Waxing and waning, increasing and decreasing,
It runs into the incalculable.
Going up to the heavens it becomes rain and dew;
Going down to the earth it becomes moisture.
The myriad things cannot be produced without it,
And the events of the world cannot culminate without it.
With its magnitude embracing all living creatures,
It is without private likes;
With its beneficence extending even to the paltry insects,
It is not after gratitude.
Having given to the world it is nevertheless not exhausted in its riches;
Having bestowed on the people it finds this to have cost nothing to its bounty.
It is ever flowing yet we can never see it reaching its end;
It is minute yet we can never hold it in our grasp.
Strike it and you will not wound it;
Stab it and you will not injure it;
Hack at it and you will not sever it;
Put fire to it and you will not burn it.
Being fluid it flows and follows its own inclinations;
Mixing and coalescing,
It cannot be divided up.
Its sharpness is such that it can penetrate metal and stone;
Its strength is such that it can give succor to the entire world.
It moves into the realm of the formless
And soars above the elusive and ethereal;
It meanders through the river valleys
And swells over into the vast wilderness.
In its abundance and insufficiency
It allows the world to take from and to give to it,
Dispensing to the myriad things without favoring anyone.
Hence, without distinction between private and public
It inundates with a thunderous roar,
Forming one vast expanse with the universe;
Veering neither left nor right
It circulates and mingles,
And has its beginning and end toghther with the myriad things.
This is called supremely excellent (de).
The reason that water is able to attain supreme de in the world
is because it is moist and lubricioius.
Thus, the teachings of Lao Dan state:
"The most pliant substance in the universe
rides roughshod over the hardest.
Emerging from that which is without substance,
it enters that which is without seam.
Thus, I know tha advantage of nonaction.' "
The formless
is the great ancestor of things,
and the soundless
is the great progenitor of the audible.
Light is the son
and water is the grandson of the formless,
and both are born out of it.
Light can be seen but not grasped;
Water can be stroked but not be destroyed.
Thus, among things that can be delineated,
None occupies a position more exalted than water.
"Coming out means life and going in means death"
is taking the step from nonbeing into being,
and then from being back into nonbeing,
and having done so, the first step towards decline into baseness has been taken.
Hence, limpidity and tranquillity
are the acme of de,
pliancy and weakness
are at the nub of dao,
and vacuity and serenity
are the use of the myriad things.

will hardly be able to sustain the state.
Only he who is merged with Grand Harmony
and holds fast to the Responses of the Natural
has the capacity for such things.
Therefore, when Mount Yáo collapsed, the Pp2lò [River] dried up.
When Qū the Smelter was born, the Pure Sword (Chúnggōu) was forged.
When Zhòu ruled without [following] Dào,
Zuǒqiáng served his minister.
Because the Grand Duke lived through two generations,
King Wǔ's undertakings were successful.
Looking at it from this angle,
the paths of benefit and injury,
the doors of prosperity and misfortune,
cannot be discovered through seeking.
Dào and Dé are related to each other
like tanned leather [helmet] and rough leather [body armour]:
if you leave them (the helmet and body armour, i.e. Dào and Dé) far apart, then they (injury and misforturn) reach you;
if you keep them tight together, then they (injury and misfortune) are kept away.
When the lute-tuner strikes the Gōng note [on one instrument],
the Gōng note [on the other instrument] responds;
when he plucks the Jiǎo note [on one instrument],
the Jiǎo note [on the other instrument] vibrates.
This results from having corresponding musical notes in mutual harmony.
Now, [let us assume that] someone changes the tuning of one string in such a way that it does not match any of the five notes,
and by striking it
sets all twenty-five strings resonating.
In this case there has as yet been no differentiation as regards sound;
it just happens that that [sound] which governs all musical notes has been evoked.
Thus, he who is merged with Supreme Harmony
is beclouded as if dead-drunk,
and drifts about in its midst in sweet contentment,
unaware how he came there;
engulfed in pure delight as he sinks to the depths,
benumbed as he reaches the end,
he is as if he had not yet begun to emerge from his origin.
This is called the Great Merging.
When the red hornless dragon and the green horned dragon roamed the land of Jì,
the sky was limpid and the earth undisturbed.
Venomous animals caused no harm;
flying birds, no terror.
They (the red and green dragons) entered thick growths,
fed on grass seeds
which they savoured in their mouth bit by bit,
and their course did not exceed the space of a hundred mǔ .
So, the mudeels disparaged them,
presuming they were no match for them in rivers and seas.
But, let the somber clouds meet with the bright sky
and Yīn and Yáng struggle with each other,
bringing down storms of wind and rain.
Then they (the red and green dragons) would be carried upward by the storm.
Their awesomenenss moved Heaven and Earth,
their din shook all within the seas.
Great sea turtles and alligators plunged down a hundred fathoms.
Black bears and brown bears took to the mountains and hills on all fours.
Tigers and leopards huddled in caves, not daring to roar.
Gibbons and small monkeys toppled down and pitched forward, missing the tree branches.
How much more should this be the case, then, for the mere mud-eels!
When the male and female phoenixes flew in their highest perfection,
thunder and lighting did not strike down,
wind and rain did not break loose,
river valleys did not flood,
nor did grass and trees [even] quiver.
So, the sparrows derided them (the phoenixes),
maintaining they could never compete with them (the sparrows) in [flying] between the eaves and ridgepole [of the hayloft].
But came the moment when they (the phoenixes) soared aloft ten thousand yards,
swirled beyond the Four Seas,
flew over the Wild Garden (Shūpǔ) of the Kūnlún [Mountains],
drank from the gushing waters at Polished Needle Mountain (Dǐzhù),
zigzagged over the banks of the Vale of Darkness (Méngfán),
skirted the borders of the Land of Jì,
shot directly over Dūguǎng [Mountain],
accompanied the sun to [its setting-place,] Yìjié,
cleansed their feathers in the Ruò River,
and at dusk nested in the Cavern of the Wind (Fēngxuè).
At this time,
among wild geese, swans and cranes,
there were none that were not awestruck,
fleeing for cover and sticking their beaks deep in the river banks.
How much more should this be the case with mere sparrows!
Here are instances (the mud-eels and sparrows) of having discernment about the traces of insignificant activities,
but failing to understand the origin of great affairs.
In ancient times, when Wáng Liáng and Zào Fù went charioteering,
[as soon as] they mounted their carriage and seized the reins,
[their] horses behaved with discipline and coordination.
They threw their legs in perfect unison
whether they galloped strenuously or ambled about leisurely.
Their minds were elated, their qì blended harmoniously
and their bodies were alert, light and swift.
When quietly exercising, they advanced joyfully;
when making a burst of speed, it was as if they had vanished.
They would zigzag right and left, like braided plaits;
or they would follow a set course, as if following a circle.
People of their (Wáng Liáng's and Zào Fù's) age all accounted them clever,
but they had not yet seen the truly great ones.
Take, for instance, the charioteering of Qián Qiě and Dà Bǐng.
They cast aside rein and harness,
discarded whip and lash.
Before the chariot had [even] been moved, it started off by itself;
before the horses had been given the signal, they took off by themselves.
[Just as] when the sun moves, the moon is activated;
when the stars shine forth, the firmament revolves;
and when lightning flashes, thunder claps,
[so] they (the horses, carriages and drivers) advanced or withdrew, contracted or stretched,
without leaving any visible trace.
Without beckoning or guiding,
shouting or bawling,
they (Qián Qiě and Dà Bǐng) would pass the wild geese returning to Jíeshí,
and overtake the phoenixes at Gūyú [Mountain].
When they (the horses) galloped, it was as if they took flight;
when, suddenly, they started away, it was as if they disappeared.
They followed arrows, treaded the wind,
pursued the whirlwind and joined themselves to the gale.
At dawn, they started out from Fùsāng
and set with the sun at Luòtáng.
It was by relying on 勓on-use' (fú-yòng) that they (Qián Qiě and Dà Bǐng) were able to achieve their usefulness,
and not through mental investigations
or manual techniques.
Whenever their inclination [for going anywhere] assumed shape in their breast,
their subtle spirits (jīng-shén) were in harmony with the Six Horses.
This is how, by 'non-driving' (fú-yù), they drove their horses.
In ancient times Huáng Dì (the Yellow Lord or Yellow Emperor) ruled all under Heaven.
Lì Mù and Taì-shān Jī assisted him
as he measured out the course of sun and moon
and regulated the qì of Yīn and Yáng,
apportioned the length of the seasons
and rectified the numbers of the calendar,
separated men and women
and distinguished male and female [animals],
made clear [the distinction between] those above and those below
and classified the ranks of noble and common.
He kept the strong from crushing the weak
and the many from oppressing the few.
The people fulfilled their life-span and did not meet with untimaly death.
Harvests ripened at the propitious time, and were not damaged by any calamity.
The Hundred Officers were upright and devoid of self-interest.
Those above and those below were harmonious and not fault-finding.
Laws and orders were clear and there was no confusion.
Ministers were public-minded and not partial.
Land-tillers did not transgress balks,
and fishermen did not wrangle over deep-water channels.
People did not appropriate what had been left along the road,
and the prices were not fixed in advance in the market-place.
[The gates of] inner and outer city walls were left unlocked,
and manors were free from thieves and robbers.
Rustic folks
mutually yielded goods to each other,
and dogs and pigs spat out grain and millet on the roadside.
All were devoid of aggressive hearts.
Thereupon, sun and moon shone with pure briliancy,
and stars and constellations did not lose their courses.
Wind and rain came at seasonable times,
and the five grains grew to maturity.
Tigers and leopards did not bite recklessly,
and birds of prey did not strike at random.
Male and female Phoenixes swirled over the court-yard,
and the Qílín roamed about the open fields outside the city walls.
Green Dragon propelled the carriage,
and Flying Yellow [horses] reclined in the stables.
Of the northern states of Dān-ěr,
there were none that did not offer their tribute and skills.
Yet this [Age of Huáng Dì] still did not come up to the Dào of Fú Xì.
Turning back to ancient times,
the Four Pillars were shattered
and the Nine Provinces dislacated.
The sky did not cover [the earth] completely;
nor did the earth uphold [all of the sky].
Fire roared with inextinguishable flames,
and waters gushed forth in powerful and incessant waves.
Ferocious animals devoured the good people,
and birds of prey snatched away the old and weak.
Thereupon, Nǚ Wā fused together stones of the five colours with which she patched up the azure sky.
She cut off the feet of the turtle with which she set up the Four Pillars.
She slaughtered the black dragon in order to save the Land of Jì.
She piled up reed ashes with which to check the flooding waters.
When the azure sky was patched up,
the Four Pillars set up straight,
the flooding waters dried up,
the Land of Jì made orderly
and the cunning wild animals exterminated,
the good people thrived,
supported by the square earth
and embraced by the round heaven.
[The people responded to] the amenity of spring, the canicule of summer,
the rotting of autumn and the indigence of winter.
They slept on their pillow squares and rush mats.
Whatever obstructed the free circulation of Yīn and Yáng,
they opened up and put in order.
Whatever perverse qì and destructive things
might do damage to what the people had abundantly accumulated,
they cut short and halted.
At that time,
they would go to rest carefree and calm,
and arise with a serene unblinking gaze.
One of them might think he was a horse
and another might think he was an ox.
Their gait was slow and unsure,
and their gaze beclouded and blurred.
In their rustic simplicity they all enjoyed harmony,
no one knowing where it came from.
They drifted aimlessly, not knowing what they were seeking,
[just as] the Wǎngliǎng Demon knows not where it goes.
At that time,
of the wild birds and animals, insects and reptiles,
there were none that did not sheathe their claws
and store away their venom and poison,
and none that displayed predatory and voracious dispositions.
If we examine their (Fú Xì's and Nǚ Wā's) meritorious achievements,
they reached to the Nine Heavens above
and touched the Yellow Clay below.
Their fame was celebrated by later ages,
and their glory pervaded the Ten Thousand Things.
They rode the thunder chariot,
using winged dragons as the inner pair
and green dragons as the outer pair.
They clasped the magic jade tablets
and displayed their charts.
Yellow clouds hung inter-woven [to form a coverlet over the chariot]
as they (the whole retinue) were preceded by white serpents
and followed by speeding snakes.
Drifting aimlessly,
they led the ghosts and spirits
and ascended the Nine Heavens,
where they paid court to the Lord at the Sacred Gate
and remained reverently silent in the presence of the Great Ancestor.
Even then, they would not extol their own merit,
or trumpet their own fame.
[Rather,] they concealed within themselves the Dào of the True Man
and thereby followed the unchanging course of Heaven and Earth.
How was this [possible]?
With their Dào and Dé they communicated with what was on high,
whereas their knowledge of factual matters was obliterated.
Coming to the time of Jié of Xià,
rulers were benighted and unenlightened.
Dào was dissipated and uncultivated.
They rejected the benevolent punishments of the Five Emperors
and did away with the laws and codes of the Three Kings.
As a result, the perfect Dé was obliterated and not diffused;
the Dào of the [Five] Emperors was blotted out and did not flourish.
In undertaking affairs they offended the azure sky,
and in issuing ordinances they were at variance with the four seasons.
Spring and autumn withdrew their harmony,
whilst Heaven and Earth cast aside their Dé.
Rulers of men occupied positions [of power], but did not bring peace.
Grand ministers concealed Dào and did not speak out.
Officials fulfilled to the last detail their superior's desires and embraced what fitted [these desires, rather than what was inherently right].
They rended bone from flesh (destroyed kinship relations) for their own interest.
Evil men got together in twos and threes and plotted secretly.
They interposed themselves between ruler and minister, father and son,
and vied for chariots (wealth and prestige).
They puffed the ruler and imitated his every wish.
They perverted others to achieve their goals.
In these conditions ruler and minister turned their back to each other,
relatives (bone and flesh) were estranged [from each other] and did not associate.
The established (state) altars dried up and cracked.
The ceremonial hall shook and collapsed.
Dogs wailed and entered deep pools.
Pigs held rushes in their mouths with which they bedded themselves in the dark corner of the house.
Beautiful women disheveled their hair,blackened their faces and applied no make-up.
Fine singers swallowed charcoal, withdrew within themselves and did not sing.
In mourning people did not exhaust their grief;
nor in hunting did they fulfill their joy.
The Old Mother of the West broke her hair ornament in two,
and the Yellow God sighed and moaned.
Flying birds suffered damaged wings,
and running animals suffered injured feet.
Mountains were bare of towering trees,
and flatlands empty of deep pools.
Foxes and monkeys headed into burrows.
Horses and oxen escaped and were lost.
Fields were barren of growing grain,
and roads denuded of reeds and hemp.
Gold ingots were chipped at their edges,
and jade disks through repeated [handling] lost their delicate markings.
The tortoise had holes (bored in its shell) until it had no undershell left,
and the divining stalks were cast day after day.
In the later generations,
the Seven States set up clan differences.
The feudal lords codified [their own] laws,
and each differed in his practices and customs.
The Vertical and Horizontal Alliances divided them,
raising armies and attacking one another.
When they laid siege to cities, they slaughtered mercilessly,
overthrowing the nobles and threatening the innocent.
They dug up burial mounds
and scattered the bones of the dead.
They built more powerful war chariots
and higher defence ramparts.
They dispensed with the principles of war
and were conversant with the road of death,
clashed with mighty foes
and ravaged without measure.
Out of a hundred [soldiers] who advanced, only one would return.
Their fame enjoyed a spurious amplitude.
In these circumstances, the able-bodied and light-footed
were made armoured soliers
a thousand lǐ away,
while family elders and feeble ones remained at home,
sad and sick at heart.
Menials and stable-grooms
pushed carts and distributed rations [to the soldiers]
along endless roads
in biting frost and snow,
and their coarse felt clothing did not [even] cover them completely.
Others, exhausted, their carts falling into pieces
and road mud reaching up to their knees,
pulled one another by the hand along the highways.
They struggled with their heads on the road,
fell prostrate on the cross-bar of their chariots and died.
What the expression "annex states and appropriate the land" meant was
several hundred thousand recumbent bodies
and smashed chariots by the hundreds and thousands.
Those who sustained injuries from bow and crossbow, spear and lance, darts and rocks,
helped and supported one another, along the roads.
The world finally reached the point where people used human skulls as head-rests,
ate human flesh,
pickled human livers,
drank human blood,
and relished these more than the flesh of grass- and grain-fed animals.
Therefore, from [the beginning of] the Three Dynasties and afterwards,
the [people of the] world were never able to soothe their heart and mind
and find joy in their traditions and customs,
or to insure their natural span
and escape untimely death caused by human cruelty.
Why was it so?
The feudal lords fiercely attacked [one another],
and the world failed to unite and form one family.
Coming to the present time,
the Son of Heaven reigns supreme,
sustaining [all] with Dào and Dé,
assisting [all] with human-heartedness (jén) and equity (yì).
Those close [to him] offer their wisdom,
and those far removed cherish his Dé.
[Simply] by clasping his hands on his breast and stretching them forward,
the Four Seas pay abeisance
and in spring and autumn, winter and summer
offer their tribute.
The whole world coalesces and becomes one,
sons and grandsons succeeding one another.
Such was the way in which the Five Emperors greeted the Dé of Heaven.
Even the sage ruler
cannot create the time.
The time comes along, and he does not miss it.
He promotes the competent
and dismisses those who show the slightest penchant for slander and flattery,
cuts short clever disputations
and does away with mutilating laws,
brushes aside petty and troublesome affairs
and obliterates the first traces of rumours,
shuts the door to cabals and cliques,
gets rid of [conventional] knowledge and ability,
and enhances the office of Minister of Ceremonies.
He (the sage) dissolves his limbs and body,
casts out [sense] knowledge,
merges with formless obscurity,
unloosens his mind, sloughs off his spirit
and becomes blank as if soulless,
causing the Ten Thousand Things one by one to return to their Root.
This, then, is how to follow in the footsteps of Fú Xī
and revert to the Dào of the Five Emperors.
How explain that Qián Qiě and Dà Bǐng
used neither rein nor bit
and were nevertheless renowned throughout the whole world for their excellent driving?
How explain that Fú Xī and Nǚ Wā
did not set up laws and measures
and were nevertheless treasured by later generations for their perfect virtue?
They reached empty non-being and pure unity,
and did not peck at vexatious affairs.
The Book of Zhōu says:
"[When] he who nets ringed pheasants fails to catch any,
he changes [his techniques] to accord with their (the pheasants) habits."
Now, let us take the manner in which Shēn [Puhai], Hán [Fēizǐ] and Shāng Yāng managed government.
They plucked up the stem [of good government]
and weeded out its roots,
without investigating wherefrom it grew.
How did they get to this?
They forcibly created the Five Punishments
and practiced cutting and slicing,
thus turning their back on the root of Dào and Dé
and fighting over the tip of an awl.
They mowed down the Hundred Surnames (the people) like grass
and exterminated more than half of them.
Then, inflated with self-satisfaction, they prided themselves on having performed [the tasks of] government.
This is like adding fuel wood in order to put out a fire,
or boring holes to stop water.
Now, stump shoots may grow on the wooden casing of a well, obstructing the bucket from reaching the bottom;
and branches may grow on the side beams of a canal, obstructing the passage of boats.
But three months will not pass before they (the growths) will surely be dead.
Why is it so?
[Because] these [growths] were all born haphazardly, lacking their own roots.
That the Yelllow River makes nine turns to flow into the sea
without being stopped [by any obstacle]
is due to its being carried forward by the Kūn-lún [Mountains].
That flood waters, however, do not flow
but spread out to the limit of one's gaze
if it does not rain for a full month,
their waters dry up and leave a stagnant swamp
is due to their being the result of mere accumulation and lacking a source [of their own].
This may be compared to Yì requesting the drug of immortality from the Queen Mother of the West.
Héng É stole it and fled to the moon.
[Yì] was dejected and forlorn,
having no way to perpetuate it (the drug).
Why was this, then?
[Because] he did not know wherefrom the drug of immortality grew.
Therefore, to beg for fire is not as good as to obtain a fire-maker.
To depend on [other people's] water is not as good as to dig a well [of one's own].
The art of the ruler is
to deal with things through nonaction
and to disseminate wordless instructions.
Limpid and still he does not move;
even when moved he is not agitated:
taking advantage of the course of things he delegates responsibility to subordinates and,
he does not wear himself out.
Even though he is aware of how things should be done, he allows himself to be guided by the imperial tutors;
even though he himself is able to speak, he allows his dispomats to proclaim the ceremonial words;
even though he himself is able to walk, he allows his escort to lead the way;
even though he himself is able to hear, he allows the administrators to select the right advice.
Therefore in his deliberations he does not decide on any wrong courses of action
and in his movements he does not err.
His words are refined and elegant
and his actions are a worthy model for the world.
His comings and goings are timely
and whether he acts or not is consistent with the implicit principles of things.
Beauty and ugliness do not stir up his likes and dislikes,
and punishments and rewards are not accompanied by anger or pleasure.
He lets each name name itself
and each class classify itself.
Things proceed from what is naturally so
and nothing arises from him personally.
Therefore a king of antiquity
would attach a veil of pearls to his cap
to prevent himself from seeing to clearly;
He would have yellow silk plugs in his ears
to prevent himself from hearing too keenly.
The emperor being surrounded by screens
was to erect a barrier around himself.
When what is to be governed is distant,
one should focus on what is close at hand;
when what is to be ruled is great,
one should preserve the small.
For him to be wild and willful in the use of his eyes would lead to excess;
to be wild and willful in the use of his ears would lead to confusion;
to be willful in the use of his mouth would lead to disorder.
These three gateways
must be carefully guarded.
Where one seeks to regulate something,
he is in fact going contrary to it;
where he seeks to embelish something,
he is in fact harming it.
A person's spiritual souls come from the vapors of heaven;
his sentient souls come from the vapors of earth.
Returning these to their mysterious apartments
and causing each to dwell in its proper residence,
if one is able to watch over these and not lose them,
he achieves communion above with the Great One.
And the essence of the Great One
communes with heaven.
The Way of heaven is mysterious and silent
and is without any movement or fixed pattern.
It is too great to be measured to its ends
and too deep to be fathomed.
Constantly being a companion to the process of transformation,
it is beyond his comprehension.
In ancient times when Shén Nóng governed the empire,
his spirit did not gallop out from his breast,
his wisdom did not extend beyond the four directions,
and he cherished the benevolent and sincere mind.
The sweet rains fell at the proper time
and the five grains flourished.
In spring they would sprout forth, in summer they would grow,
in autumn they would be harvested, in winter they would be stored up.
With monthly examinations and seasonal evaluations,
at the year's end the record of accomplishments would be offered up,
and tasting the grain at the proper season,
sacrifice would be made in the Míng Táng.
The institution of the Míng Táng was such
that it had a roof and no walls,
but the elements could either enter it
nor do it harm.
With a halting manner he would enter it.
Nurturing his people in justice,
they became plainly honest and sincere.
Without contending one with the other, they fould that they had plenty;
wearing themselves out they achieved their ends.
And taking advantage of the stock of the heavens and earth they lived in perfect accord with their natural enviroment.
His intimidating presence was awesome yet not put to the test,
punishments were there yet he did not have to invoke them,
and his laws were few in number and not overwhelming.
Hence his transformation of the people was godlike.
In his territory stretching from Jiāo-chih in the south
to Yōu-dū in the north,
Ta１ng-gǔ in the east
and Sān-weī in the west,
there was no one who would not submit to his rule.
At this time
the laws were liberal, the punishments were toerant,
and the prisons were empty.
The world was one in custom
and none were of a wicked mind.
The government in declining age is a different matter:
Those above are fond of taking without any conception of proper limit
while subordinates are self-assertive and wholly given over to avarice.
The people, impoverished and distressed, contend angrily,
and working themselves to the bone, never achieve anything.
Cleverness and deception sprout forth,
bandits and thieves are increasingly evident,
ill-will appears between superiors and subordinates,
and edicts and orders are not implemented.
The authorites do not devote their efforts to returning to the right path.
Going against the roots, they cultivate the nonessentials;
cutting back on their bounty,
they increae their punishments.
And yet by doing such things they are trying to establish proper order!
This is no different from holding a catapult and hoping to attract a bird,
or wielding a cane to tame a dog.
It will just make matters worse.
Now where water is muddy the fishes gasp;
where government is cruel the people are disorderly.
Those who breed tigers, leopards, rhinoceroses, and elephants
put them in pens, [make pens for them]
provide for their desires,
feed them at the right time,
and give them room to vent outbursts of temper.
But notwithstanding this, that the animals do not live out their natural span of years
is because they are physically under duress.
Where superiors escalate their cleverness, their subordinates will be that much more deceptive;
where superiors escalate their interference, their subordinates will be that much more self-seeking;
where superiors intrude on the people without respite, their subordinates will be that much more unsettled;
where superiors escalate their demands, their subordinates will wrangle all the more among themselves.
Working at the nonessentials
rather than straightening things out at the root
is like prodding a pile of dirt to put down the dust
or bringing an armload of firewood to extinguish a fire.
The sage governs easily because his affairs are few,
and the people are easily satisfied besause his demands on them are few.
He is benevolent without giving,
he is trusted without speaking,
he gets without seeking,
he accomplishes without doing.
Solitarily he preserves what is genuine,
embraces virtue, and promotes simcerity.
And the word follows him
just as the echo responds to the sound
and the shadow to the form.
This is because he cultivates the root.
Punishments and penalties are inadequate to change social custom;
executions are inadequate to put an end to wickedness.
Only godlike transformantion is estimable
and only the most essential vapors can do it in this way.
Now, a loud shout cannot be heard beyond a hundred paces,
but where the mind is focused it
will make itself understood several hundred miles away.
In the winter the myriad things seek out the sun
while in summer they seek the shade.
There is nothing which casues this yet it is so.
With the appearance of the most essential vapors
things come without being summoned
and depart of their own accord without being dismissed.
Dark and abstruse,
no one knows who produces them
and yet their achievements are naturally realized.
The wise are not able to speak of them
and the eloquent are not able to describe them.
In ancient times Sūnshū Aó reposed peacefully
and yet gave the men of Yǐng no opportunity to use their weapons.
Yí Liáo of Shì-nán toyed with his pellets
and yet even with the trouble existing between the two families there was no opening for either side to express their views.
Things like armor
and grimaces of wrath
are a far cry from an effective defense against arms;
things like contracts and ceremonial gifts,
punishments, penalties, and instruments of execution
are of little use in resolving difficulties;
the method of relying on your eyes to see
and your words to command
is fraught with difficulties in effecting proper order.
When Qú Bóyù became prime minister,
Zǐ Gòng went to see him
and asked,
"How do you govern the state?"
He replied,
"I govern it by not governing it."
Jiǎn Zǐ, wanting to attack Wèi,
sent Shǐ An4 to go and make a preliminary examination of situation.
Returning, he reported:
"With Qú Bóyù as prime minister,
the time is not yet right to attack."
How could any kind of fortificaitons
have such an effect!
It was when the mute Gāo Yáo became minister of justice
that the world was free of cruel punishments.
This was because he had something of greater value than the spoken word.
It was when the blind Shī Kuàng became prime minister
that Jìn was free of disorderly government.
This was because he had something of greater value than sight.
It was orders without words
and seeing without looking
that were the methods that made Fú Xī and Shén Nóng fit to be mentors.
In being transformed, the people
follow what the ruler does rather than what he says.
Duke Zhuāng of Qí spoke against strife
while in deed being fond of courage.
As a result, the state was raked by turmoil
which led in due course to his assassination at the hands of Cuī Shū.
And King Qǐng Xiāng spoke against promiscuity
while in deed being fond of women.
As a consequence, his people were extremely unruly
which led ultimately to the problem of Zhāo Qí.
The effects of the most essential vapors,
such as the spring vapors giving life
and the autumn vapors extinguishing it,
occur even faster than
the speed of a post horse or a courier.
The ruler is
like an archer.
Where his aim is off to the slightest degree,
he will miss the mark by yards.
Because of this, he is cautious in how he moves the people.
On hearing Róng Qǐqī play one chord on his lute,
Confucius was delighted for three days.
This was because he was moved by its harmony.
On hearing Zōu Jì strum his lute once,
King Wēi of Qí grieved all night long.
This was because he was moved by its plaintive sound.
Whereas one is able to arouse delight and grief in others
by articulating his feelings
in the sound of the lute and lyre,
he cannot alter customs and conventions
by proclaiming laws and establishing rewards.
This is because [in the latter case] his sincerity of mind is not projected abroad.
Hearing Níng Qì's melancholy song which came from beneath the ox cart,
Duke Huán [of Qí] sighed and took a second look.
This shows how deep the most essential vapors touch others.
It is said:
With music, if one hears its sound,
he will know what kind of customs there were,
and if he sees the customs,
he will know how the people were transformed.
That Confucius studying the lute under Master Xiāng
understood the purposes of King Wén
was because on seeing the faintest outline he could fill in the rest clearly.
That Jì Zǐ of Yánlíng on hearing the music of Lǔ
knew the customs of the Yīn and Xià dynasties
was because on classifying what was close at hand he could infer what was far away.
The culture produced in high antiquity
and lasting a thousand years
is still with us,
how much more so the influence of this on the people of that era.
At the time of King Tāng of Yīn
there was a seven-year drought.
When he offered himself as sacrifice on the outer reaches of Sāng-lín,
the clouds from all quarters of the world gathered
and rain fell for hundreds of miles around.
Embracing simplicity and offering his sincerity,
he moved the heavens and earth.
If his spirit can make itself understood even in the realm beyond,
how could his orders being carried out and his prohibitions being observed
have caused him any difficulty?
With the sage-kings of antiquity, when the most essential vapors were embodied within,
likes and dislikes did not lie on the outside.
Their words were spoken to express what was truly on their minds
and they issued commands to show their purposes.
Setting these out in social norms and music
and recounting them in song and verse,
their deeds have been known to each succeeding generation
and have spread to every corner of the world.
They could even shape and transform
birds, beasts, and insects.
How much more so could they administer the law and implement edicts.
The highest ruler is godlike in his transformations.
Next comes one who makes it impossible for people to do wrong.
and next comes one who rewards those of superior qualities and punishes the troublemakers.
Because the crosspiece of a pair of scales
shows no bias toward either the right or left in weighing,
it can be level.
Because a plumb line
shows no bias toward inside or out in measuring,
it can be straight.
Because the ruler in administering the law
shows no bias toward those he likes or dislikes,
his words can be command.
It is by depending upon a given method
and dispensing with the human element
that in weighing things the scales are percise to the smallest fraction of an ounce,
that in strainghtening things the plumb line is accurate to a hair's breadth,
and that in redressing any warwardness or deviation
the ruler is wholly free of personal perjudice or bias.
Deviousness cannot make him bend,
slander cannot disturb him,
he gives no ground for gratitude
or ill-will.
Such rulers, in relying on art, dispense with the human element.
Hence cleverness plays no part in government.
Now, a boat floating on water
and a vehicle rolling along the land
are both natural to their circumstances.
Why, on running into a tree and breaking the carriage axle
or running onto the rocks and staving in the boat,
does one not feel ill-will toward the tree or the rocks but rather holds the skill of the driver or boatman to blame?
The answer is because there is no deliberate intention on the part of the tree or the rocks.
Where the Way is accompanied by intelligence, there is confusion;
where good deeds are accompanied by a motive, there is treachery;
where the mind is accompanied by the eye, there is bedazzlement.
No weapon is as piercing as a fixed purpose娞ompared to it,
even the Mò-xié sword is inferior;
no invaders are as great as the yin and yang娞ompared to these,
even the attack drums are insignificant.
Now the scales, the compass, and the square
once fixed cannot be changed.
They do not compromise their integrity for the sake of Qín or Chǔ
nor do they change their semblance for the sake of the Hú or Yuè people.
Being constant, they do not vary;
being used for a special purpose, they do not adapt themselves.
Having once been cast,
they are passed on through ten thousand generations
and operate through nonaction.
It may be that a nation has a doomed ruler,
but there is no such things as the useless Way;
it may be that man has reached the end of his tether,
but principles never fail to be applicable.
Viewing it from this perspective,
nonaction
is the source of the Way.
When one gets hold of this source of the Way,
he is never at his wit's end in responding to things,
but when he relies on the talents of men,
it is difficult to reach the acme of good government.
Even sage-rulers such as Tāng and Wǔ
would be uable to match the Yuè people in maneuvering a small craft on the rivers and lakes.
Even an outstanding minister such as Yī Yǐn
would be unable to match the Hú people in breaking to harness the fine horses of the north.
Even men as broad in understanding as Confucius and Mò Zǐ
would be unable to match the mountain people in foraging about the thicket and scaling perilous slopes.
Viewing it from this perspective,
human intelligence is very limited in its capacity to deal with things.
If a person, hoping to light up the whole world
and see clearly in all directions,
relies exclusively on it
rather than on the inevitable outcome of practicing the Way,
it will not be long before he reaches a dead-end.
Thus it is that individual human intelligence is not adequate to the task of bringing proper order to the world.
Jié's strength
was such that he could split a horn, unbend a hook,
plait iron, fuse metal,
and maneuver a great ox about;
in the water he could kill a giant turtle
and on land he could capture a bear.
Nevertheless, Tāng leading only three hundred war chariots
surrounded him at Míng-tiáo
and then captured him at Jiāo-mén.
Viewing it from this perspective,
outstanding strength and boldness are not adequate to the task of retaining control of the world.
Since human intelligance ais not in itself sufficient to effect proper government
and boldness is not in itself sufficient to hold sway,
it is clear that
individual human talents cannot be relied upon.
This being so, where a ruler
comprehends circumstances even beyond the four seas
without ever leaving his ancestral hall,
it is because he takes advantage of things to understand things
and he takes advantage of man to understand man.
Where concerted strength is applied,
it is equal to any task;
where the intelligence of the many is employed,
it will succeed in all things.
That household wells do not host giant turtles
is because they are too cramped;
that flower gardens do not produce huge trees
is because they are too small.
A person will be unsuccessful in lifting a heavy tripod
if he has inadequate strength.
But when it comes to removing it,
he does not neccessarily have to rely on one person with a great deal of strength.
A community of a thousand people has no broken bridges,
and a settlement of ten thousand people has no abandoned projects.
Now, the two famous horses, Huá Líu and Lǜ Er3,
would cover several hundred miles in one day.
But if one set them to catching rabbits,
they would be outdone by a wild dog or a wolf.
This is because their faculties and abilities are different.
During the night an owl can snatch a flea or mosquito out of the air
and discern even the tip of an autumn hair.
But during the day, stetching its eyes wide open,
it cannot even see a mountain or hill.
This is because it is contrary to its nature for it to do this.
The teng snake springs up into the mists;
the flying ying dragon ascends into the sky mounting the clouds;
a monkey is nimble in the trees
and a fish is agile in the water.
In ancient times in the construction of a carriage,
the varnisher did not do the ornamental drawing
and the engraver did not wield the adze.
A worker did not have more than one skill,
a scholar did not combine two offices.
Each kept to his own province
and did not interfere with others;
each person found his niche
and each thing found its place.
As a result, products were not of inferior quality
and duties were not neglected.
Where the debt is small it is easy to repay;
where duties are few they are easy to fullfill;
where a person's burden is light he is easy to encourage.
With the ruler making only very limited demands
and his subordinates presenting him with accomplishments easily achieved,
sovereign and ministers will never become tired of each other.
The Way of the ruler
is like the impersonator of the spirit at the sacrifice to the líng star.
Being solemn and mysteriously silent,
he auspiciously receives his blessing.
One who embodies the Way does not make himself up because he is ugly
or serve as a standard for the good.
It is a cape not too big for one man to wear
nor too small for ten thousand.
If the ruler exercise the same caution before bestowing favors as he does in being severe,
the Way of proper government will prevail.
"To bestow favors"
is to set store in largess.
When those who do not give good service are richly rewarded
and those who do not exert themselves receive high rank,
ministers with defined duties will grow negligent
and persons who do not hold office will press for appointment.
"To be severe"
is to punish without grounds.
When the innocent are executed
and the upright are punished,
the well-disciplined will not be encouraged toward good conduct
and the wicked will think nothing of defying their ruler.
Bestowing favors is a source of villainy
and being severe is a source of strife.
And villainy and strife
are the prevailing winds in a doomed state.
Thus it is that under the administration of a perspicacious ruler,
where the state carries out punishments, the anger of the ruler is not involved in them;
where the court bestows rewards, the ruler plays no part in them.
Those who are punished fell no ill-will toward the ruler.
This is because it is what their crimes deserve.
Those who are rewarded feel no gratitude to the ruler.
This is because it is the result of their good service.
Because the people know that the source of punishment and reward
lies in themselves,
they try their best to make themselves fit to carry out their occupations
and do not feel indebted to the ruler.
There are no footprints in the court which is overgrown with wild grass;
there are no weeds in the fields which have been well-cleared.
Thus the most excellent ruler
is one of whom his subjects know only that he exists.
Now, the upright on the shadoof, being fixed vertifcally, does not move,
and yet the crosspiece in moving up and down is controlled by it.
The ruler being still and silent is not restless,
and yet the bureaucracy takes its measure from him.
This can be likened to the standard bearer of an army
if he signals indiscriminately, chaos will ensue.
Cleverness is inadequate to the task of bringing about a great peace;
intelligence is inadequate to the task of dispelling danger.
Rather than praising Yáo and reviling Jié,
we do better to put aside the ability of eyes and ears and return to cultivating the Way.
If the ruler is limpid, still, and nonactive,
the heavens will provide him with the proper seasons.
If he does not appropriate what is not his, is frugal, and keeps to moderation,
the earth will yield him up its bounty.
If he is content with being stupid while praising the virtues of others,
sages will lend him their counsel.
It is to the low ground that the myriad things repair
and to the empty that the empire gives its gifts.
(When the ruler listens to state affairs,
his vision should be clear and unobscured,
and his mind should be open and free of preconceptions.
As a result, the various ministers will converge on him side by side like spokes at the hub,
and irrespective of intelligence or moral character,
all will strive to do their best.
He can then commence to set out his code of social conduct
and establish it as his basis.)
This is (for the ruler) to mount a chariot which is the overwhelming support of the people,
and to drive horses which are the intelligence of the people.
Even on a remote or treacherous stretch of road,
there is no fear of his not knowing which way to go.
Since the ruler dwells deep in seclusion
to avoid the heat and damp,
and remains behind layer upon layer of doors
in order to protect himself against villainy and insurgency,
within he knows nothing about the towns and villages
and without he knows nothing about the mountains and valleys.
Beyond the curtains and hangings,
one's eye cannot penetrate further than a few miles
and the ear cannot hear beyond a hundred paces.
Even so, he is wholly cognizant of all
that goes on within the world
because the sources that feed him are immense
and those who tap him are numerous.
Hence, without going beyond his doors, he knows about the world;
without peeping out through his window, he comprehends the heavenly Way.
When the ruler avails himself of the intelligence of the people,
gaining the empire is a task hardly worth doing,
but when he relies exclusively on his own mind,
the preservation of even his own person cannot be guaranteed.
Putting the whole world under his bounty
instead of bringing his own intelligence into play,
the ruler follows what the people find beneficial.
Now, by lifting his heel, he is able to benefit the empire.
Hence he takes his place above
and yet they do not find him heavy;
he dwells in front of them
and yet they do not find him an obstacle;
though they raise him up, they do not feel that he is too high;
though they support him, they do not grow tired of it.
The Way of the ruler is said to be round
because, revolving and turning, it is without a starting point.
He transforms and nurtures like a god,
is vacuous and vacant, and follows the natural course of things.
Always keeping to the rear, he never takes the lead.
The Way of the minister is said to be square
because he finds out what is appropriate and dwells in what he is best fitted for.
It is by taking the lead in carrying out affairs
and by clearly keeping to his defined duties
that he realizes his accomplishments.
Where the ruler and minister have different Ways, there is proper order,
but where they are the same, there is disorder.
If each gets what is appropriate to him
and dwells in what is right for him,
the one above and those below will know how to deal with each other.
When the ruler listens to state affairs,
he should be empty of mind and weak of resolution,
and his mind should be clear and unclouded.
For this reason, when the various ministers are like spokes converging side by side at the hub,
and irrespective of intelligence or moral character,
all do their best,
then the ruler has the means to hold control over his ministers,
the ministers have the means to serve their ruler,
and the Way of ordering the state properly is clear.
Because King Wén though himself intelligent was given to consulting others,
he became sagely.
Because King Wǔ though himself redoubtable was given to consulting others,
he became victorious.
If one rides on the intelligence of the people,
there is nothing which cannot be carried;
if he employs the strength of the multitude,
there is no task to which he is not equal.
A weight of eight tons
could not be lifted even by Wū Huò.
But if the people were to act in concert,
a hundred men would have more than enough strength.
Hence if one relies on the strength of one man,
even a Wū Huò cannot be counted upon,
but if he takes advantage of the intelligence of the people,
then ruling over the whole world is a task hardly worth doing.
Yú diverted the course of the Yangtze and dredged out the Yellow River
in order to benefit the world,
but it was not within his ability to make the waters flow westward.
Jì cleared the land
in order to encourage farming among the people,
but it was not within his abililty to make grain grow in winter.
It is not that anything humanly possible has been left undone,
but that this was not possible in the nature of things.
Now to attempt what circumstances render impossible
instead of following what natural principles make inevitable is something
even a saint or a sage would be unable to achieve success in
how much less so the ruler of our present age!
Where the cartload is heavy and the horses are emaciated,
even a Zào Fù would not be able to drive far;
but where the cart is light and the horses are good,
even a person of mediocre abilities can drive along at a fast pace.
It is not as if the sage could possibly
go against what natural principles make inevitable in accomplishing things,
or run contrary to what is natural
in making the bent straight
or the contracted outstretched!
He always takes advantage of what a thing can be used for and uses it accordingly.
Where concerted strength is applied,
no task is too great;
where the intelligence of the people is engaged,
no undertaking will go unfinished.
A deaf person can be made to chew the animal sinew used in covering bows,
though he cannot be made to hear.
A dumb person can be made to work in the horse stables,
though he cannot be made to speak.
This is because their physical persons are not whole
and their abilities heve their limitations.
That which has a specific form can occupy a position appropriate to it
and that which has a specific ability can undertake a task appropriate to it.
When the strength of a person lifting a burden is equal to the task,
he does not feel it too heavy to raise;
when the ability of a person pursuing a task matches it,
he feels no difficulty.
When everything large or small, long or short,
finds its niche,
then there is equality in the empire
without anything being able in any way to surpass another.
Because the sage used both big and small, long and short,
there is no wasted ability.
The ruler sets high store in integrity and conscientiousness.
Where men of conscientiousness and integrity are in authority
and preside over affairs with propriety,
sycophants and villains will have no avenue of approach.
It is like the square and round being unable to overlap
and the bent and straight being unable to admit each other.
That birds and animals do not run together
is because they are a different class of creature.
That the tiger and deer do not gambol about together
is because they are unequal in strength.
When a sage gets his way and is on the throne,
those sycophants and villains who want to intrude on him
are like a sparrow encountering a hawk
or a mouse running into a badger
they are at the end of the line!
Now in every move, the ruler
must exercise great care.
If the one who is entrusted is the right person,
the state will be well-ordered,
the relations between superiors and subordinates will be harmonious,
the various ministers will be devoted to him,
and the common people will bend to his will;
but if the one who is entrusted is the wrong person,
the state will be in peril,
superiors and subordinates will be at variance,
the various ministers will fell ill-will,
and the common people will be disorderly.
Therefore, if any move is inappropriate
it will be a bane on him for the rest of his life.
The key to success or failure in government
lies in the ruler.
If the inking line is properly set above,
the wood will be straightened beneath it.
It is not that the inking line does anything in particular to the wood,
